title: Mordiford Dragon Trail Walking Route

images.title: Tony Bailey / Mordiford church, bridge and post office.
images.caption: Mordiford church, bridge and post office. Heavily used medieval bridge. The grass area in the foreground floods regularly in the winter. There are wonderful tales of dragons associated with both the church and the river crossing.

images.title: Pauline Eccles, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Holy Rood Church, Mordiford. A central tower survived until around 1811 and was replaced with the present SW tower. Until 1811 there was a painting of a large green dragon on the tower wall.

images.title: Upper Mordiford, from the Wye Valley Walk by David Purchase, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Upper Mordiford, from the Wye Valley Walk. The Dragon of Mordiford was said to reside just outside the village, at the confluence of the River Lugg and the River Wye.

images.title: Old Corn Mill (Mordiford) by Fabian Musto, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Old Corn Mill (Mordiford)

images.title: Mordiford Bridge and Mill by Chris Allen, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Mordiford Bridge and Mill

images.title: Jonathan Billinger / The Pentaloe Brook
images.caption: The Pentaloe Brook. This stream drains the centre of the Woolhope Hills to the east of Mordiford.

images.title: Hope Springs, Mordiford by David Purchase, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Hope Springs

images.title: Old buildings in Mordiford by Jeremy Bolwell, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Historic buildings on the edge of the village.

description: This short walk celebrates Mordiford’s fascinating Dragon legend, taking you through some lovely local countryside and woodland on the way. On the walk look out for a series of wonderful wooden sculptures which illustrate the tale of the dragon that once lived in Mordiford. There's also information panels with more details of the story and the local wildlife you can see on the way. To continue your walking in the area try the longer Mordiford Loop. Part of the walk also uses a section of the Wye Valley Walk. You could follow this waymarked trail south to visit neighbouring Fownhope which visits the bluebell woodland in Fownhope Park before heading to the adjacent Haugh Woods .

details.subtitle: Pubs/Cafes
details.content: The splendid Moon Inn is a fine choice for some post walk refreshment. The friendly pub does very good food and has a fine selection of ales too. Outside there's a large beer garden for warmer weather. You can find them at a postcode of HR1 4LW for your sat navs.

display_address: B4224, Bagpiper's Tump, Mordiford, Herefordshire, England, HR1 4LN, United Kingdom
